content: pretty cool right I don't rewind it rewind I'll still be
here back good today we're going deeper underground so this is how I do cave
tots begin by measuring and cutting foundations from double corrugated
cardboard as normal cut all of them at two and a half inches light squared for
caves I recommend making filled tiles single wall tiles and curves you could
do straight hallways if you like but I didn't make any in this video anyway
draw a crude shape on the tile indicating where the outside of the wall
is going to be do this for the single side wall tiles as well trust me I've
tried to skip this and having a perfectly straight cave wall really
sticks out and doesn't look very good one extremely important point these
lines which again describe the outside of the wall must begin and end precisely
at the corners of the foundation with your crafting knife cut freehand along
your lines to obtain some irregular looking foundations
now pull out about one square foot of aluminum foil crunch it down into a thin
roll that is about a quarter-inch thick note you can probably get away with
using half this amount just don't crunch it down so densely now form the foil rod
along the shape of a foundation and cut it to length do this twice hot glue one
of them to the foundation then glue the other one on top to obtain a double high
rough looking wall next cut up some one and an eighth inch chipboard squares as
in video to glue them to the foundation if next to a wall cut them down to the
proper shape to fit up against the wall as was described in video four note that
these squares should not be touching there should be an eighth inch gap
between them this means you'll place them a sixteenth
of an inch from the edge of the tile as shown here now comes the most
painstaking part the idea for using crinkled aluminum foil for cave textures
came directly from the dmg take a sheet of foil and delicately collapse and
uncollapse it to create a wrinkled texture then cover the tile with it
including the corrugation I use white glue on the surface and hot glue along
the corrugation this seals the edges instantly and allows me to move on with
the workflow without having to wait for the white glue to dry underneath
gently press along the edges of the squares beneath to reveal a subtle grid
through the foil from here paint the tile using the colors of your choice
now let's step back to the very beginning and demonstrate a different
method of doing these again cut your foundations at two-and-a-half light and
again draw erratic lines and cut along them to obtain irregular foundations and
again crunch down foil into a quarter inch thick roll dry fit them cut to
length and glue to the foundation at this point is where we do things
differently instead of covering the entire tile with crinkled foil only
cover the wall specifically cover the entire three-quarter inch height of its
outside along the top and the half inch height on the inside draw a thin bead of
hot glue across where it meets the inside corner of the wall and then rough
it up quickly using your finger or the nozzle of the hot glue gun this will
seal down that edge of tin foil for the corrugation use your quarter-inch thick
very thin cardstock strips as described in video 2
next take your 1 and an eighth inch chipboard squares and round the corners
don't be shy here I recommend more rounding than you did on the dungeon
tiles then dry fit these spaces to the tile and once again cut the odd shapes
needed in order to butt them up against the walls
wrap each piece of chipboard in a small piece of crinkled foil
then hot glue it to the foundation notice I didn't bother with white glue
on the inside by wrapping the chipboard completely all of the exposed foil edges
should be underneath and when the hot glue spreads out it simultaneously
attaches the space and seals the foil in place from here
paint using the colors of your choice here's what I did
base completely in black then apply a coat of dark brown with the brush at an
extreme angle so as not to load the deepest details with paint they should
remain black the neck here is identical to that for the wood planks from video 7
be sure to hit the cracks between the spaces and along the corrugation cover
with the dark brown third apply a light dry brush of a highlight color I used
pebble if you're brand new to painting let me
save you some wasted experimenting it will be tempting to dry brush in white
and get a really nice pop don't it will overwhelm the piece and you won't even
see the nice erratic Brown mid layer that you did okay and so in typical Y
lock tradition fly through at the end with terrible jilted banter so here's a
small cave here's our hero and the texture came out really nice you could
see DM G's idea was really solid it pays dividends so maybe there's an OD ugh
here in this cave and he's going into haunted or kill it or something but that
is not a pretty sight alternatively maybe it's bronze dragons lair or
something like that this would be I think an adult or what a three-inch I I
don't recall but so maybe he's gone and that would be a good thing because they
are of a generally good disposition so that's those do a little rearrangement
here and show how easy it is to make interesting shapes hallways generally at
an angle that's how you see them drawn but again if you wanted to make a
straight hallway or a two wall tile you certainly could so easily reconfigurable
and here's an arrangement of the first method that we tried these actually have
a code of semi-gloss on them to give them a wet cave like feel also a little
tip they're hot glue pennies to the bottom gives a good weight to the tile
keeps it in place handles nicely so again the hero and the miniatures
that we showed a minute ago personally I don't like this style I have switched to
the first one that we looked at a moment ago because you look at the seams of
this tile they really stand out because they're not the same as the subtle grid
that's imprinted so it just doesn't look cohesive those raised spaces those
chipboard you know stones on the other method really help to mask the seams and
the same is true for the dungeon tiles in the first few videos of the series
also so I've pretty much abandoned this method but if you like it or you can
improve it a go for it maybe you could do this but corrugation cover instead of
tin foil because that tends to add some bulk on the side there so that's it two
methods for your money's worth that's how I do cave tiles thank you very much
for joining me and I hope to see you next time why lock signing off
you
